text: ANGLE ON A SINGLE COTTONWOOD LEAF... brown and crisp... clinging to its empty branch... the solitary sign of life an otherwise barren tree.
A gust of wind... the leaf breaks free... flutters down, landing in the slow current of the Missouri. The last lea of the fall, taking its final journey south.

As it floats along the surface, rising and falling with t current, all we can hear is the river's gentle movement.. the trickle of water... the splash of timid rapids... unt DISTANT VOICES invade this world... soft at first, but growing louder... LAUGHTER... SINGING.

And then our leaf CRASHES INTO A WOODEN BOARD... the BOW BOAT. We hear the VOICES EVEN CLEARER... MEN'S VOICES, as rise up the bow... see it's a FLATBOAT BEACHED ON A SANDB at the center of the river.

Beyond the flatboat are the voices... TWENTY MEN of the R Mountain Fur Company, making camp along the shore... haul wood, building campfires, pitching squares of canvas for makeshift rooftops. And this camp is full of life because these are some of the first men to ever see this untouche wilderness... men with a whole new world just waiting for them to claim their share.

CAPTAIN ANDREW HENRY, (late 20's), dressed in a buckskin jacket with long fringe... thick belt pulled tightly arou his waist with two pistols and a knife hanging from it. H stands out among the others... like an imposter pretendin be a member of some exclusive club. He pulls off one of h gloves... examines the BLOOD-FILLED BLISTERS lining his p
From across the camp, JOHN FITZGERALD, (40's), solid and thick... dark eyes of a killer, watches Henry. He nudges MACE BOONE, (40's), a thief in a previous life.
Likely got a splinter. Can't figure what to do without Mama here to pull it out for him.
Boone chuckles... spits in Henry's direction. 2.
Need a doc, Captain?
Henry looks up... sees Fitzgerald and Boone grinning at h He slides his glove back on.
Gather more wood.
Fitzgerald waits for Henry to turn, then gives his back a exaggerated salute.
(under his breath) Shame my Pap was a broken down drunk. Else he could've bought me a Captain's job too.
Boone snickers. Fitzgerald stomps his boot onto a branch, easily snaps it into two easy-to-carry pieces.
We got a plan for these fires, Captain, or are we roastin' berries all the way up to Fort Union?
Glass and the others will be back with some game, Fitzgerald. Just make sure you have the fires ready.
My supper's in the hands of a hermit nigger, a kid and a dummy. Hell, my belly feels full already.
Fitzgerald's boot CRACKS another branch... and when it do we hear the EXPLOSION OF A GUNSHOT.
And a CLOUD OF SMOKE surrounding the LONG BARREL OF AN ANSTADT RIFLE.
The smoke fades, and at the other end of the rifle we see face of HUGH GLASS, (40's), African-American, one eye sti closed, as the other calmly stares down that barrel.
Shit fire, you got him, Mr. Glass! 3.
Glass lowers the rifle, as PIG GILMORE, (30's), fat and filthy, races past.
Square as a barn door.
JIM BRIDGER, (17), young eyes that have already seen a lo nods to Glass as he follows Pig.

Glass watches Pig and Bridger trot through the trees to a fallen ELK. Glass walks calmly after them, graceful in th world... his rifle so comfortable in his hand it's like h was born with it there. Pig crouches over the dead elk... grins up at Glass.
Right where you said he'd be.
But bigger than we figured. Gonna be a load to haul back to camp.
Have to split it up I reckon.
Yep. Bridger'll take the tail, and Pig you haul the rest.
And Fitzgerald was right about Pig being a little slow, because he just nods... pulls out his knife to cut the ta off for Bridger.
Bridger and Glass exchange a smile... until Glass notices something... steps over the elk, his eyes locked on the ground beside it. He runs a finger over the dirt... touch a broken twig.
Another one close by?

Glass doesn't answer... studies the track... feels the ne brush... inhales the scent from his hand. Bridger and Pig watch him... exchange a confused glance. And then in a fl of movement, Glass is on his feet, racing away.
Hugh?
Glass just keeps running. Pig and Bridger chase after him
The men building fires... laughing... enjoying themselves Boone on the outskirts, gathering branches.
...dodging trees... leaping over fallen logs... loading h Anstadt as he runs.
...but not as gracefully. Pig trips... slams to the ground... scrambles back to his feet to continue on.
...seeing other men playing cards. He stops along the edg of camp, drops the wood to the ground.
No rule says I'm the only one that's gotta gather this shit.
The other men don't even notice. Then an ARROW WHIZZES THROUGH THE AIR from behind Boone... THWACK... it hits hi the back of the neck... erupts out the front of his throa

Boone stands frozen... confused... reaches up and grabs t bloody arrow... finally drops to his knees. And that's wh a TRAPPER looks up... sees Boone on his knees, holding th arrow, his mouth open like a dying fish.

head_text.subj: AND BEYOND BOONE ARE FORTY ARIKARA WARRIORS CHARGING THRO
THE TREES... FEATHERS RISING FROM THE MOHAWKS SPLITTING T
SHAVED HEADS... FACES PAINTED FOR BATTLE.

text: WHOOSH... AN ARROW SAILS INTO THE TRAPPER'S CHEST, sendin him flying backward. The camp explodes into chaos... men YELLING... grabbing for weapons... stumbling over each ot as they duck behind trees. 5.
...taking aim at the attacking figures.

The Arikara pour into camp, arrows flying... knives and hatchets swinging. And this is a massacre... the Arikara wading through the trappers... stabbing... clubbing... scalping. This once peaceful world is filled with a sicke mix of war cries and screams of death.

Fitzgerald rises up from behind a log... aims his rifle.. BOOM... takes down one of the warriors. He starts reloadi as ANOTHER WARRIOR charges him... draws back his knife. Fitzgerald pours the powder, but knows he isn't going to it in time... the warrior leaps toward him...
...BOOM... it's like the warrior hits an invisible wall.. flies back to the ground, very dead. Fitzgerald spins... sees Glass and his Anstadt right behind him.
Fitzgerald takes off... flips his rifle around, swings it like a club across a warrior's head... WHACK!

Henry shoves a TRAPPER toward the water. An arrow drives into the trapper's leg... he goes down. Henry lifts the m to pull him into the river, but several more arrows bury the man's back... he falls limp. Henry FIRES HIS PISTOLS, dropping the WARRIOR.
Bridger and Pig join Glass... splash into the river, SHOO back at the attacking Arikara. The water deepens, and the start swimming toward the flatboat.
ARROWS HISS into the water all around them.
Glass is still in the shallows... aims his pistol... BAM. shoots an oncoming warrior... spins after the other men.. joins them as they near the flatboat.
A final TRAPPER charges down the shore behind them. SEVER WARRIORS pursue him.

He aims his pistol over his shoulder as he runs... pulls trigger... CLICK... pulls it again... CLICK. But he's too scared to stop his finger... CLICK... CLICK... CLICK... THUD... as a hatchet buries in his back. He crashes face first into the shallows.

The Arikara leader, (ELK'S TONGUE), animal bones braided his mohawk, a NECKLACE OF HUMAN EARS around his neck, straddles the dying man. Elk's Tongue grabs the Trapper b the hair, and CUTS OFF HIS LEFT EAR, then holds it up to Glass and the others, as he SCREAMS HIS WAR CRY.
Glass and the men shove the flatboat off the sandbar... s scrambling aboard, as arrows dart past them... drive into wooden boat.

Suddenly a WARRIOR EXPLODES FROM THE WATER... tackles Bri as he climbs up the side of the flatboat... jerks him bac into the river. Bridger flails in the water... watches th warrior raise his hatchet high to slam down... just as Gl SLAMS THE BUTT OF HIS ANSTADT into the back of the Warrio head.
The Warrior collapses under the surface. Glass grabs Bridger's hand... drags him up onto the deck.
Thank you.
But Glass is already gone... FIRING BACK AT THE ARIKARA, the current carries them away.
Pig looks over the side... sees a frantic WILLIAM ANDERSO gripped to the edge. Pig pulls him onto the boat.
Fitzgerald and Glass grab LONGPOLES... shove them against river's bottom to pick up speed.
Henry stands on deck, watching as Elk's Tongue yanks a DY TRAPPER's head back by his hair to peel away his scalp.
Henry drops his eyes... can't watch. The TRAPPER'S SCREAM ECHOES OVER HIM.

Quiet and dark... the battle long over. The flatboat floa with the gentle current. The NINE SURVIVING TRAPPERS are scattered around the deck... 7. Glass digging an arrow out of WALLACE MURPHY'S SHOULDER.. Fitzgerald poling on one side with Anderson on the other. STUBBY BILL VANCE and Pig standing patrol with their rifles... Bridger doctoring a badly WOUNDED TRAPPER... an Henry standing at the front of the flatboat, staring off blankly.
What's the plan, Captain?
Henry's still lost in those screams.
Captain! What the hell do we do now?
Henry snaps out of his stare... turns to the men... obvio doesn't have an answer.
We're just floatin' farther from Fort Union.
Henry's eyes instinctively look to Glass.
The Missouri's no good. Not if the `Ree's running it.
So we just float the hell down to Mexico or wherever else this river takes us?
We get ourselves safe outta range, then track another course up.
Add weeks to the trip.
Better that than endin' up scalped on the side of the river.
(shoving him away) Shut up, kid, you don't get no say in this.
Bridger starts to respond, but Fitzgerald's angry glare s him. 8.
(back to Henry) And in case you hadn't noticed, Captain, we're twelve men short of what we were. (off the badly wounded
Thirteen before long.
I understand our situation, Mr. Fitzgerald. We do like Glass said... put some distance between us and the Arikara, then chart a course to Fort Union.
Fitzgerald MUMBLES UNDER HIS BREATH... rolls those dark e to Anderson. Glass gives Henry a nod.

head_text.subj: THE BADLY WOUNDED TRAPPER... NOW DEAD...

text: ...as hands push the body over the side of the boat. It splashes into the water... floats downstream.
We PULL BACK... see that the flatboat is beached along th bank of the river. Glass and Pig watch the body drift awa
Reckon it's better `an lettin' the `Ree find him... take his ears... slice what's left all to shit.
Glass nods... steps down off the boat to Henry and the others. They're gathered around a map spread out on the ground. Henry runs his finger along a THIN BLUE LINE.
So we hike west to the Grand, then follow it up to Fort Union.
On foot? You got any idea how long that's gonna take? It'll be winter before we get there.
Unless we come across a post... trade for some horses. 9.
No posts that far out.
So if we do this, we do every step with our own feet.
We make camp here for the night, then load supplies and head out for the Grand at first light.
And gather extra blankets `cause there won't be any fires.
More GRUMBLING from Fitzgerald and Anderson, as they move toward the cover of trees. Bridger walks up beside Glass.
Thank you... for what you done back there.
You'd have done the same for me.
Bridger nods... he hopes so.

Pig on watch... sitting at the base of a tree, rifle acro his lap, eyes wide, scanning the darkness. All clear. He peers back to camp... Fitzgerald, Anderson, Stubby Bill, Murphy wrapped in blankets... passing a bottle of whiskey around. Bridger across from Fitzgerald, poking at the dir with a stick. Henry is off to one side, still studying th map. Glass sits against a tree, cleaning his Anstadt rifl
Fitzgerald watches Glass a beat, then...
You treat that Anstadt sweeter than any woman, Glass.
Never seen a woman that could stop a `Ree from three hundred feet.
I knew a particular big-breasted redhead in Boston that might come close. 10.
The others manage a small laugh. Glass just keeps working that rifle.
Bring it over here for me to have a look.
Glass doesn't look up... wipes a rag down the barrel.
Did you hear what I said, boy?
Still nothing from Glass. And Fitzgerald doesn't like that... the tension's growing.
You seen it before.
Fitzgerald turns that mean, drunken glare on Bridger.
What'd you say, kid?
Bridger hesitates a beat... until the other men's eyes fo a response.
I said you shoulda already got a look when he saved you with it earlier.
The camp falls still... nobody talks to Fitzgerald like that... especially when he's drunk. There isn't a sound except for Glass working methodically on his rifle...
...until the SWISH OF BLADE OVER LEATHER, as Fitzgerald t the blade from his belt... flings it into the dirt betwee Bridger's legs... AN INCH BELOW HIS CROTCH.
Fitzgerald stares at Bridger, daring him to react. But Bridger's too scared... doesn't, so Fitzgerald just smile
You're lucky you ain't a man yet. (off the blade) Else that mighta nicked somethin'.
A few NERVOUS CHUCKLES from the others, hoping this is ov And it is, because Fitzgerald reaches over and pulls the knife away... cleans the dirty blade on Bridger's leg. 11.
And unlike you, I don't need savin' by him or nobody else. Remember that.
Fitzgerald stands... wobbles just a bit. He slides the kn back into his belt, then steadies his drunken gaze on Gla
The others exchange nervous glances... uh-oh.
Fitzgerald walks to Glass... snaps his fingers for Glass' Anstadt.
Lemme see what's so special `bout that shooter of yours.
Nothing from Glass, so Fitzgerald grabs the barrel, but G holds firm.
Middle of workin' on it.
Well you can stop workin' on it, and let me have a look like I said.

Fitzgerald gives another tug, but Glass' grip only grows tighter. His eyes roll up to Fitzgerald... make it clear isn't giving up his rifle. And they hold that stare just hard as they're holding Glass' rifle.
You forget your place?
Best I can tell, my place is right where I want it... on the smart end of my rifle.

Fitzgerald realizes the barrel he's holding is aimed righ his stomach, while Glass' hand seems suddenly very close the trigger. But Fitzgerald's pride and that whiskey won' let him lose this tug of war.
I'd be careful if I was you, boy.
And this thing's about to turn real ugly... until...
That's enough, Fitzgerald. Go sober up and get to sleep.
If you're passed out when we break camp tomorrow, I leave you here.
Fitzgerald holds his glare on Glass, then releases the ri shoving it back at Glass. He glances to Henry, and throws back a big gulp from the bottle just for spite, before backing away from Glass.
That's the trouble with this part of the world. No mirrors. Niggers forget what color they are.
Glass ignores Fitzgerald... goes back to his rifle. Fitzgerald tosses the bottle at Anderson, then jerks his blanket up... walks off to sleep by himself.
Glass glances up from his work... just long enough to giv Bridger a nod.

Fitzgerald sleeping off that whiskey. The others snoring a cluster at the center of the camp. Henry lies there awake... looks across to Glass, still sitting against the tree, a HANDRAWN MAP in his lap, as his eyes pierce the darkness. Henry eases over to Glass.
Can't sleep either?
Never like closin' my eyes when I'm not sure who'll be standin' over me when I open `em.
I keep thinking about Boone and the others... how maybe I should've had us make camp further up river.
The tracks I saw... those `Ree had been tailin' us for a while. They'd have gone as far north as it took.
You're a good man, Captain. Soon as you realize that, these others will too.
Henry likes hearing that... still isn't sure it's true. 13.
Your years trappin' and guidin' out here... have you had much experience with the Arikara?
Enough to try and stay outta their way.
(motions to Glass' map) But you know this country well enough to get us past them... up to Fort Union?
I been here a long while. Whether that gets us to Union or not...
Henry waits for more... doesn't get it. So he just nods a starts back to his blanket.... stops.
What Fitzgerald said earlier... he doesn't speak for the rest.
He wasn't wrong. Truth is that's what I prefer about this country... it's got no eye for the color of a man's skin.
Try to get some sleep, Hugh.
Henry climbs back under his blanket. Glass just sits ther looking at the map.

...primitive at best. Sketched mountains... winding blue lines for rivers... small dots are scattered about with n beside them... "Brazeau", "Talbot", "Union". And DOZENS O TRIANGLE PINE TREES have been drawn, representing the end wilderness.
We TIGHTEN ON THOSE TRIANGLES until we're lost in them.
Thick with trees. Henry leads the men single file through the woods. They each have a canvas sack of supplies over shoulder, and their rifle in their hands.
The only sound is their feet crunching the dried leaves, even that seems too loud as their eyes dart about, search for any sign of attack.
Shouldn't we have hit the Grand by now?
We'll reach it soon enough. Glass said to keep this course.
Glass said. Too bad I don't see him.
That's on account he's up ahead makin' sure it's clear, and you get to keep your ears.
Fitzgerald throws Pig an angry glance.
Or he's run off and left us.
He wouldn't do that.
Fitzgerald GRUNTS... doesn't believe that.
My bet, that nigger's used to runnin'.

Glass moves slowly through the brush, almost gliding... subtle twists and turns to avoid branches and leaves... careful not to leave his scent behind. And his eyes cut through the trees as he moves... digging for any sign of movement.
He spots something at his feet... crouches down, running finger over the SMALL ANIMAL TRACK in the dirt. 15.

O.S. RUSTLING snaps his head up... to the TREMBLING OF BUSHES... growing harder... whatever's in there is coming toward Glass. He calmly raises his rifle... presses the stock firmly against his shoulder... closes one eye as he takes steady aim down the long barrel...
...to the shapes rumbling out of the brush... TWO BEAR CU playfully wrestling.
Glass lowers the Anstadt... looks past the cubs for somet else... but the woods are empty. A SUDDEN FEAR FILLS GLAS EYES...

...he spins... right into the GIANT GRIZZLY SWINGING ITS AT HIM... hitting him across the side of the neck. The animal's razor claws tear into Glass' throat, as the forc sends him flying through the air.

Glass sails into a thick tree... the CRACK OF HIS LEG SNAPPING against the trunk. The rifle falls from his hand The Grizzly lets out a massive ROAR... charges Glass. Gla crawls to the Anstadt... grabs it... has just enough time tilt the rifle toward the bear... BOOM.
Henry takes off at full sprint. The other men follow.

...tosses Glass aside with a powerful swing. Glass hits t ground with a PAINFUL THUD. He starts CRAWLING AWAY, pull the KNIFE from his belt as the bear rises up like a giant behind him... swings... tears its claws across Glass's ba shredding deep into his flesh.
Glass is fighting for his life now... flailing with the knife... slicing it across the bear's paw as it whips pas him. The wound slows the bear enough for Glass to start crawling again.
But the Grizzly doesn't give Glass the chance... ROARS... on him in a flash, a BLUR OF CLAWS AND FANGS... tearing across Glass' head... ripping into his face... his chest. 16.
Glass drives his knife into the bear again... deep... try to tear through the layers of flesh to something more vit

...locked in a death grip... tumbling along the ground... trading violent blows... Glass' blade versus the Grizzly' claws and fangs... snapping small trees as they roll over them... toward the edge of a steep embankment...

... and ROLL DOWN... spinning over and over... each ROARI AT THE OTHER... Glass pounding the knife into the bear ag and again as they fall... neither willing to surrender as they careen down the slope at a dizzying pace, then SLAM THE BOTTOM WITH A CRUNCH. And the forest falls still... Glass hidden somewhere beneath the massive animal... both deathly motionless.

Bridger's the first to reach the battleground... sees the FRIGHTENED BEAR CUBS SCURRY AWAY. He follows the bloody ground and crushed underbrush to the top of the slope... looks down to the mass of flesh at the bottom.
Christ Almighty.
Henry, Pig, and the others reach the edge.
Glass!
No answer. And all they can see is the bear, so they scan the trees.
Still nothing. So Bridger takes off down the slope... los his balance but rolling back to his feet. He reaches the bear... sees GLASS' MANGLED ARM STICKING OUT FROM BENEATH 17.
He's down here!

Bridger uses all his strength to push the bear off, as th other men scramble down. But Bridger can't budge the mass carcass... not until Stubby Bill and Pig join in... shove animal over, revealing the bloody mass that is Hugh Glass

...his throat is torn wide open... scalp peeled back from just above his eyebrows, hanging off the skull... stomach chest a gruesome design of gashes and cuts. His right leg is snapped, the jagged bone jutting out through the skin.
Bridger's legs give out... he drops to a knee and vomits.
Oh, Jesus.
He's tore to pieces.
The men stare down at Glass' corpse.
Least he took that Grizz down with him.
Wished he'da done it without firing his rifle. If there wasn't no `Ree around before, there will be now.
And that's all Pig can stand... he TACKLES FITZGERALD... roll to the ground. And in a flash Fitzgerald is on top, raining punches down on Pig... turning his face into a bl mess.
Henry and Anderson grab Fitzgerald... drag him off.
Then somehow, GLASS GASPS... this horrible, GUTTURAL MOAN
Holy Christ, he's alive.

Henry and Bridger fall to their knees beside Glass. Glass looks up at the men, tries to focus through the blood and pain. His breathing is just a GURGLING WHEEZE... bubbles forming along the deep gashes in his throat with each gas 18.
Get me some water.
Stubby Bill tosses Henry his canteen. Henry empties it ov Glass' throat... his face and scalp. The water hits the wounds and immediately transforms to blood.
Oh, Jesus... Jesus.
Glass lifts a trembling hand to his throat... feels the gaping wound. His eyes widen in horror. He COUGHS... the air splashes blood up from the open wounds in his throat.
It's okay, Hugh. (pushing Glass' hand away) You're going to be fine.
Henry spins his head away from Glass.
I need some rags before he bleeds out.
Pig whips a shirt from his bag... shreds it.
And your whiskey.
Pig tosses a bottle to Henry. Henry pours it over the gashes. The BURNING PAIN arches Glass... he CRIES OUT in that same horrific moan.
Hold him down, Bridger, goddammit.
Bridger throws his weight against Glass' shoulders.
The rest of you spread out... scout a circle around us. Fitzgerald, you and Anderson take west and north. Murphy and Mike south and east. Watch for anyone that might've heard that shot.
And for the first time, Henry seems like a leader of men. firm... in complete control... just as Glass said he woul be. So the men hurry off to their positions. 19.
What about me, Cap?
Get down here and help me tie off these wounds best we can.
Pig shakily joins Henry in wrapping the wounds. The blood keeps seeping out, soaking the rags.
It won't stop bleedin'.
Shut up, Pig.
We're fixing you up, Hugh.

Glass is like a shredded rag doll... dazed eyes staring u them as they work on his wounds... wrapping the rags arou his throat... laying his scalp back over his skull, and t another rag around it and under his jaw to hold it in pla
Bridger wipes the blood from Glass' face.
It's gonna be fine, Mr. Glass.
Henry glances down to the PUDDLE OF BLOOD spilling out ov his knees... oozing out from beneath Glass.
Roll him over... easy.
They gently push Glass onto one side, revealing DEEP, JAG GASHES running across the width of Glass' back. Henry sta at the open flesh, ready to panic again... but he doesn't Instead he looks to Pig.
Get me the kit. We need to stitch his back up.
What about the rest of him?
He's losing more blood back here. (off the throat) And I don't know what to do with that yet. 20.
Pig digs out a thick needle and spool of black thread... hands it to Henry. Henry grabs the whiskey bottle.
I'm sorry for how this is about to burn, Hugh.
Henry pours the whiskey over Glass' back. And the pain mu be excruciating, because Glass lets out a HORRIBLE WAIL.

Fitzgerald and Anderson standing watch together in the tr Glass' scream erupts through the trees, and they both immediately crouch down to a knee... out of sight to anyo out there that might have heard that.
They're torturin' the poor bastard.
And riskin' gettin' us killed in the process. Proper thing would be to end it for him quick.
`Less he could pull through.
You seen what that grizz did to him. Shit, Glass'll be dead inside a hour. We all will be if he keeps screamin' like that.
HENRY, BRIDGER AND PIG WORKING OVER GLASS... Bridger and pressing Glass' scalp down, as Henry slides the needle an thread through the skin, suturing the wound.

head_text.subj: BRIDGER AND PIG HOLDING THE SCREAMING GLASS DOWN AS HENRY
SNAPS GLASS' LEG BACK IN PLACE.

text: FITZGERALD PEERING BACK THROUGH THE TREES... to Henry doctoring Glass. Fitzgerald shakes his head in anger... turns back to the darkening forest.

Glass rests unconscious on the ground. Two branches act a splint on his leg. A blanket covers his body... his face like a swollen, disfigured, Frankenstein's monster... stitches of black thread holding it in place.
Henry crouches a short distance away from him, rinsing hi hands under a canteen. Bridger and Pig stand beside him.
What now?
We wait. Does he have any kin you know of?
He keeps to hisself. Never mentioned none.
Go get the others. Tell `em we're making camp here for the night.
Pig starts hustling away.
And gather some wood, but make sure it's dry. We don't want much smoke when we cook that grizzly.
...lying dead on the ground, its claws and fangs soaked w blood... Glass' blood.
And what's left of the grizzly... its fur cut away... sla of flesh butchered from its skeleton.

A fire burns at the center of camp... a chunk of meat roa above the flame. The men sit around the fire... 22. Murphy reaches up... tears a strip of meat from the roast tossing it in his mouth. The men are silent... the pall o Glass' attack still hanging over them.

Bridger rises... walks to the Grizzly... crouches down ov it, grabbing the animal's enormous paw. It dwarfs his own hand, as he examines the claws. Bridger pulls out his knife... stretches the claw out to its full length, and C IT OFF AT ITS BASE.
What makes you think you earned a claw?
Bridger turns with a start... sees Fitzgerald standing ov him, meat in his hand... his lips shiny with the grease.
You didn't take that grizz down.
It ain't for me.

Bridger stands... walks over to the sleeping Glass. Pig's already crouched beside him. Bridger lifts Glass' small leather POSSIBLES BAG from beside the Anstadt rifle... dr the claw inside... throws a look back to Fitzgerald.
Pig holds his palm out just above Glass' mouth.
I can feel some air outta his mouth. Maybe Captain sealed up his throat proper, huh? (off Bridger's silence) Whatta you figure his odds are, Jim?
Bridger stares down at what's left of Glass.
Long.
The sun peeks over the horizon, sending an orange glow ac the treetops.
...unconscious but alive... his raspy breaths are weak an staggered. The SHADOWS OF MEN hover over him...
...because Henry and the others surround Glass, staring d at him.
What that bear did to him... I didn't expect he'd last this long.
I seen a fella go a week once after a lion jumped him. Fever finally finished him off.
Whatta we do, Cap?
A long beat, then...
We give him his chance.
Henry turns and walks away.
The fire has burned down to nothing. The men sleep scatte about. Murphy stands just outside of camp, rifle ready, keeping watch.
Glass lies there awake... eyes wide open... a living corp And his breathing is just as labored as before... raspy, blood-soaked strains.
Fitzgerald tosses and turns, listening to Glass' gurgling
You ain't doin' him or us no favors, Captain, lettin' him suffer that way.
Henry's awake, but doesn't answer. He's holding his pisto in his hand, as he stares at Glass... thinking the same t Fitzgerald just said. But he doesn't move... not yet.
Fitzgerald angrily wraps a blanket around his head, muffl the sound. Bridger sits beyond him... smiles at Fitzgeral misery, as he attaches the BEAR CLAW TO A THIN LEATHER STRAP... a necklace. 24.
Bridger kneels over a SHIVERING GLASS, holding wet rags o his head. Pig and Henry stand over them, watching.
Fitzgerald, Anderson, Murphy and Stubby Bill sit huddled across camp.
Fever's hit. Won't be long now.
I seen a bad one drag on days.
...eyes open... he can hear every word.
FITZGERALD (O.S.) (cont'd) Insides shut down... flesh starts to spoil and turn. Ain't no way for...
Quiet, Fitzgerald.
...points a stick at Glass.
We keep sittin' here watchin' him die, only gives the `Ree more chance to find us.
Henry doesn't answer... just keeps staring down at Glass.
He's burnin', Cap. Water turns to boil as soon as it touches him.
Henry considers this, then...
Pig, take Anderson and scout ahead. Grand should be just west of here. Find us the best route.
Tryin' to buy Glass time don't make sense for the rest of us, Captain. 25.
Get movin'.
Pig nods... grabs his gear. He and Anderson take off out camp. Henry turns... walks over to Fitzgerald and Stubby Bill.
You two can start digging a grave.
Fitzgerald tosses the stick away.
Least it's a step in the right direction.
Fitzgerald is covered in dirt and sweat, standing knee de in Glass' grave. Stubby Bill stands over him.
Any coyote digs that deep deserves the meal.
He takes Stubby Bill's hand... pulls himself out.
Glass won't know the difference no ways.
Pig and Anderson walk back into camp.
Found it, Cap. Right where Glass had us headed.
No more than a mile or so out.
Henry looks to Bridger, still doctoring Glass.
We could build a litter. Haul him with us.
It's rocky and steep goin'.
Henry looks to Pig for an honest answer. 26.
Marshy and thick on the other side. We could try it, but...
Pig shakes his head.
I signed on as a trapper, not a goddamn mule.
Shape he's in... I don't see no way he'd make bein' drug.
Henry nods, his mind racing for a solution. And before lo his hand is back on that pistol. He pulls it from his bel
The other men all drop their heads... except for Fitzgerald... he's ready to see this end.
Henry stares down at Glass.
Lay that rag over his eyes, Mr. Bridger.
But, Captain.
Do it.

Bridger hesitates, then reaches to fold the wet rag down Glass' wide open eyes. And Glass must know what's happeni because his eyes roll up to Bridger's... his lips try to a word... his hand digs its fingers into the dirt beside
...the boy looking away as he pulls the rag over our eyes everything goes black.
Step clear, Mr. Bridger.
A LONG BEAT in the dark, waiting for that gunshot, then..
Henry standing over Glass... pistol aimed down. His hand trembles slightly.
Pig turns away... presses his hands over his ears.
Bridger takes a few steps back... stares at Henry.
Henry struggles to steady his aim, until finally it calms because he's thought of something else.
There's a seventy dollar bonus from the Rocky Mountain Fur Company to the two men that stay with Glass... see this through. Then give him a proper burial.
I'll stay with him... money or not.
Same here.
I can't let you stay back, Pig. Without Glass, I'll need you to scout.
Henry looks to the others... they all drop their eyes... interested.
Just need one more.
Two won't stand much chance against a party of `Ree, Captain, and seventy dollars won't buy me a new setta ears.
A hundred then.
Still nothing from the others.
They can have my share too. I owe Glass that at least.
That case I'll hang back with the kid. I don't mind fallin' a day or so behind for two hundred. 28.
But Glass is to be cared for until. Understood?
(motions to Bridger) I'll let the young doctor do his job.
Henry hesitates... doesn't like this, but knows it's the option left.
The rest gather your gear.
Bridger reaches down... lifts the rag from Glass' face. Their eyes meet... Bridger gives Glass a nod.
Henry and the others are loaded and ready to leave. Pig bends down over Glass.
I'll see ya at Fort Union, Hugh.
Glass's glazed eyes focus on Pig. He moves the only thing can... BLINKS a "yes" back at him.
(to Fitzgerald and
As long as necessary.
I'll look after him.
Henry turns... leads the men into the trees... toward the Grand... toward Fort Union.

What's left of a small fire is nothing but smoldering ash Bridger crouches beside Glass, pouring a thin stream of b between his lips. Fitzgerald reaches in... grabs Glass' Anstadt leaning against the tree.
I'll take first watch. 29.
Not with his rifle.
Trust me, kid, he ain't gonna be needin' it tonight.
Fitzgerald disappears into the trees.
Pig stands on a ridge, scouting a course. He waves back t Henry and the others. They start toward him.
Glass conscious on the ground... that same labored breath
...smiling down at Glass as he grabs the Anstadt, holds i runs his hand down the barrel, as comfortable as if it we his own.
You were right to protect this.
Then he disappears... and we're left alone, staring up at branches above us... the evening sky... accompanied by Gl deathly breaths.
Bridger kneels beside the stream, filling canteens.

Fitzgerald sits bored against a tree, twisting a knife in hands... flipping it point first into the dirt... grabbin repeating... twist... flip... thwack. And as he does, his eyes are locked on Glass. 30.
Finally, Fitzgerald snaps the knife from the dirt, stands and walks over to Glass. Glass is asleep. Fitzgerald crouches down over him... eyes his red, infected wounds.
When are you gonna die, boy?
Fitzgerald reaches out with the blade... gently touches o of the threads holding Glass' throat together. And when h does, GLASS' EYES FLY OPEN... focus on Fitzgerald.
Fitzgerald doesn't even flinch... just holds that knife t there against Glass' throat.
I'm nearly a week behind Henry's bunch on accounta havin' to tend to you. Be easier on us all if you'd take that last breath.
The two men hold a stare... until Fitzgerald pulls back t knife... grabs a bloodstained rag from beside them... bal it up in his fist.
I could help ya with that if you'd like. Muzzle ya right now... end all this sufferin' quick and easy. Nobody'd ever know you give up.
Fitzgerald moves the rag over Glass' nose and mouth... ho it there, just inches above.
You just gimme a blink if you want me to do it.
Glass locks his eyes on Fitzgerald's... both men unblinki
A DROP OF BLOOD hangs from the rag... finally falls... la on Glass' lips.
Fitzgerald almost smiles, waiting for the inevitable... a Glass stares back, fighting the urge to blink.
Suddenly Bridger's hand clamps down on Fitzgerald's shoul Fitzgerald spins... startled.
What's goin' on? 31.

Fitzgerald jumps with a start, sees it's Bridger, and is pissed that Bridger scared him... and interrupted his business. He rises quickly, planting his meaty hand in Bridger's chest, and SLAMMING HIM BACK AGAINST A TREE.
Don't you ever question me, you little piss-ant.
Bridger tries to fight back, but Fitzgerald's too strong. holds him pressed against the tree... slams a heavy elbow into Bridger's mouth, splitting his lip.
I'd just as soon leave both you and your nigger here to rot. `Cept killin' you ain't worth givin' up your share.
But that don't mean I can't be coaxed into changin' my mind.
Fitzgerald shoves him away... Bridger stumbles and falls. Fitzgerald tosses the bloody rag at him.
And I was just doin' your job... cleanin' him up.
Fitzgerald grabs Glass' Anstadt, almost daring Bridger to something. Of course Bridger doesn't. Fitzgerald walks toward the trees.

Why don't ya pour some more broth down his throat... keep him alive another week so we can fall farther back. End up walkin' all the way to Fort Union on our own. `Ree would love to poach on just two. (turns to Bridger) I promise ya, you'll look a helluva lot worse than Glass when they're done with you.
Bridger watches him disappear into the trees... wipes the blood from his lip with a trembling hand.
From high above the trees. The world is silent... peacefu until SEVERAL STARTLED CROWS shoot up from the treetops.
...the sound of FRENZIED BREATHING.
Bridger! Get your ass up!
Dim light fills the frame... then FITZGERALD'S FACE right front of us.
`Ree.
What?
Keep quiet. I was down at the creek... there's twenty of `em at least, comin' this way.
Oh, shit. Whatta we do?
We run. Now.

And Fitzgerald's just whispering, but it's with such powe that Bridger has no response... watches as Fitzgerald gat his bag, starts throwing in food and supplies. Bridger is scared out of his mind... does the same... grabs for his rifle, resting near Glass.
Bridger freezes... in his panic, he'd forgotten all about Glass. And now the wounded man's eyes stare up at him... understanding perfectly what's happening around him.
What about Glass? 33.
He's on his own, same as us.
I can't leave him.
Then I'm talkin' to a dead man.
Glass gives Bridger the slightest of nods... go. But Bridger's frozen... doesn't know what to do... until Fitzgerald shoves him back to life.
Move.
Glass reaches out a weak hand out for his Anstadt... claw for his weapon. Bridger starts to hand it to Glass, but Fitzgerald grabs it first.
What're you doin'? He needs that.
He couldn't hold it if you tarred it to his hands.
Glass strains to hold out his trembling hand for his gun.
It's his goddamn rifle! That's all he's got!
And more than he'll need.
Fitzgerald scoops up Glass' knife as well.
We can't leave him with nothin'.

But Fitzgerald is already sprinting away... disappearing the trees. Glass stares after him, his once-calm eyes suddenly filled with a rage. And Bridger's frozen again, lost between duty and fear... until finally, he just shak his head and takes off into the trees.

Glass's empty hand falls back to the ground... he tries t yell out in anger, but his throat EXPLODES IN PAIN. His h digs into the dirt... pulls him over onto his side. He fl over to his stomach... GASPS IN PAIN... 34. then using his one good arm, drags himself over the dirt, healthy leg pushing weakly at the ground, trying to prope him forward... a futile chase after Fitzgerald and Bridge
...inch by inch... farther than he's been in days. But it still only a few yards, and now he lies in the open... a clear target for the Arikara.

Then he spots that hole... the grave Fitzgerald dug for h He grunts into action... grabs SEVERAL, THIN BROKEN BRANC from the ground, then claws forward, each movement excruciating... until finally, he reaches the hole, and R INTO IT... lands with a PAINFUL CRUNCH.

He rests there a moment, trying to regain any ounce of strength. Finally he fights through the pain... shoves th branches back up... spreading them across the hole as camouflage... a thin veil, but all that Glass has.
He lies there defenseless... INSIDE HIS OWN GRAVE. Hiding listening for the Arikara's arrival... waiting to die.

head_text.subj: OUT OF THE GRAVE... TIGHT AND CLAUSTROPHOBIC
JUST THE NIGHT SKY THROUGH THOSE BRANCHES... AND THE SOUN

text: Cold and grey. Fitzgerald crouches beside a small fire, warming his hands. WHISPS OF SMOKE rise into the sky.
We ran the better part of six hours. Had to gain some ground on Henry and them others.
Bridger sits at the base of a tree, not listening... staring... his mind replaying the desertion of Glass over over. He notices the smoke.
Best douse that smoke before them `Ree spot it.
We put enough distance between us and them. And it's too damn cold to go without one. 35.
All we know, they hoofed it through the night same as us.
(shakes his head) A dozen `Ree can't make the time us two did.
Bridger looks back to the trees... then considers somethi stares at Fitzgerald a beat, before...
It was twenty earlier.
What?
When you woke me... you said you'd spotted twenty `Ree.
A dozen... twenty. I wasn't in a mood to count feathers. Hell, one `Ree woulda been too many.
Fitzgerald empties his canteen over the fire, killing the flames. Bridger stares at the water pouring out.
What was you even doin' down at the creak in the middle of the night?
I'd already brought plenty a water.
Fitzgerald doesn't answer. Bridger tightens his grip on h rifle... slowly rises.
Answer me.
Don't start questionin' me on accounta you feelin' guilty `bout leavin' your nigger buddy behind.
Bridger musters up all the courage he can... aims his rif at Fitzgerald.

head_text.subj: ANSWER ME OR I BLOW YOUR DAMN HEAD

text: Fitzgerald stares back at Bridger and his rifle... eyes taking in everything... a snake sizing up its prey. Then Fitzgerald stands... takes a step toward the boy.
What're you askin'? Why it was you turned your back on Glass? Why you let him die to save your own sorry skin?
`Cause you was scared shitless, that's why.
The `Ree... did you see `em? (off Fitzgerald's silence)
Not a one.
Bridger CRIES OUT... starts to pull the trigger, when Fitzgerald's hand flashes out, grabbing the barrel, and shoving the butt back into Bridger's face... THWACK.

The force of the blow knocks Bridger back to the ground, Fitzgerald holds his grip on the rifle barrel... flips it around to aim it at the boy. Blood drips down Bridger's h as he stares up at his rifle pointed down.
Fitzgerald's finger tightens on the trigger.
So that there is the answer to your question.
And Fitzgerald PULLS THE TRIGGER... AND BRIDGER SQUEEZES EYES SHUT IN FEAR... THEN CLICK. Bridger opens his eyes.. sees Fitzgerald sneering down at him.
And the next time you aim to kill somebody, kid, best remember your gun won't fire without a flint.

Fitzgerald tosses the rifle back at Bridger, and turns aw Bridger's face flushes with rage and humiliation... he charges Fitzgerald from behind... tackles him to the ground... starts pounding Fitzgerald with punches.

A few of them land, but it's only a moment before Fitzger is back in control... HEAD-BUTTING Bridger off of him... 37. tossing him away, then KICKING BRIDGER IN THE STOMACH... AGAIN. He grabs his knife... is ready to finish Bridger off...
...but Fitzgerald is smart enough to know that out here, are safer than one... even when one is just a kid. He sta walking away.
I'm goin' back for him.
Far as we ran all night, you couldn't find Glass with dogs and a map. And I don't believe you really want to. `Cause after leavin' him to die the first time, I doubt he'd be too happy to see you now.
Fitzgerald digs at the dirt with the knife... covers the fire's remains.
And just so we're clear. If you try to backtrack without me knowin', or ever get so guilty you feel the need to tell somebody.
Fitzgerald looks at Bridger... hard... evil.
I'll have no choice but to gut you from nuts to nose.
Fitzgerald stares his point home, then shoves the blade i his belt, and stands.
Now let's go.
Bridger wipes the blood from his face, then throws one la glance behind him before following Fitzgerald.
Empty and quiet... no sign of life... until GLASS' HAND R BETWEEN THE BRANCHES. His fingers dig into the earth, pulling himself up from the hole... a dead man climbing o of his own grave.

He rolls out to the ground... arches in pain when his bac hits the cold, hard surface. 38. Glass lies there shivering, regaining what little strengt has, then rolls over... starts dragging himself again wit that one good arm. He makes it to the blanket... wraps it around him.

Glass rests there in the center of camp... unable to move his eyes scanning the surroundings... no food... no water and he's wide open in this clearing... an easy target for predator. So he grabs his Possibles bag and GUNPOWDER HOR and drags himself toward the cover of brush.

And every movement takes all the will Glass has... a push with his good leg followed by a pull with his healthy arm inch by inch... foot by foot... sweat pouring down his fa as he finally reaches the cover of the trees... continues on... dragging himself across the forest floor in a desperate, hopeless crawl for survival.
But finally it's too much for Glass... the fever and pain overwhelm him. He collapses... falls unconscious.
Glass lies in the dirt, weak... dehydrated... starving. H looks at his hands... scratched and bloody from clawing h weight.

He unwraps his small, leather Possibles bag... dumps it t the ground, revealing it contents... flints, a straight razor, his map, and a LEATHER NECKLACE WITH THE SIX-INCH CLAW attached. Glass grabs the razor... cuts SEVERAL THIN STRIPS FROM THE BLANKET, and wraps them around his hands.
He shoves the rest back in the bag, and does the only thi he can do... start crawling again... push with his health leg... pull with his good arm.

Glass dragging himself up a steep slope... over rocks... jagged edges catching the wounds... tearing the primitive stitching. The gashes rip wider... blood oozes down, leav a crimson trail dripping down the rock behind him.
The wind is howling through the trees. Glass lies beneath cluster of brush... shivering... bleeding. Every aching breath creates a puff of smoke in the cold, night air. 39.
Thick with a sea of four-foot high Cattails... like minia cornstalks. Looking down from above the marsh we see a tw foot wide path of crushed plants that reaches the center the marsh, and stops.
We tighten on the end of the path, until we see Glass lyi among the Cattails. He's sawing off one of the stalks wit the straight razor... peeling away the husk, and eating t tender flesh beneath.
Mosquitoes move in clouds around him... over his face... arms. But Glass' injured body only allows him one action a time, so the mosquitoes have their fill of him, as he g on the Cattail.

Glass pulling himself along the ground... stopping to tea FEW BERRIES from a plant, and shove them in his mouth. He flinches as he swallows. He starts to move again, but freezes... listens... RUSHING WATER.
Glass digs his fingers into the ground with new energy... pulls himself toward the sound... up over a ridge... and there it is at the bottom of the ridge...
...THE GRAND RIVER... WATER. Glass crawls down toward it.
Glass drags himself to the river's edge, cupping handfuls water and rubbing it over his parched lips... withstandin the pain to gulp it down.
As he does, Glass notices a FISH hovering in the shallows beside him. He makes a desperate grab for the fish, but i darts easily away.

Glass cups more water to his mouth, but with each drink, feels the water leak from a hole in his throat... run dow his neck. He leans out over the surface to check his reflection... barely recognizes the swollen, stitched- together, disfigured face staring back at him. He fights the urge to vomit... pulls the razor from the leather bag and cuts more strips of blanket, soaking them in the rive then cleaning his wounds. 40.
He runs a finger up to his shredded throat... around the open, wet hole. He cups another handful of water to his mouth... strains to swallow, then feels the liquid GURGLE OF THE HOLE.

Glass shoves the cloth against the wound... tries to pres the flesh together... no good. He dumps out his Possibles bag... stares at the meager contents. He picks up one of flints... looks to the powderhorn.

head_text.subj: A SMALL CLUMP OF DRIED GRASS...

text: ...as Glass SPARKS one of the flints... ignites the grass As the fire grows, Glass pours a handful of GUNPOWDER fro the horn, and RUBS IT ALL OVER THE HOLE IN HIS THROAT.

He lifts several small blades of burning grass... a minia torch. And only then do we realize what he's about to do. because he stares at the flame a beat, then raises it tow his gunpowder-covered throat.
The flame nears the black powder, and LEAPS OFF THE GRASS igniting the powder, and SETTING GLASS'S NECK ON FIRE.
Glass falls back to the ground in agony... TRIES TO SCREA but his burning, shredded vocal chords won't allow him.
The gunpowder sizzles and burns... the flame spreads... Glass' flesh sears... melts. And the pain is too much for Glass... he passes out.
ANGLE ON GLASS... looking dead beside the river, but we k he's alive because we can hear those same painful, raspy breaths.
And then we hear something else... an O.S. RATTLING, grow LOUDER... FASTER... BUZZING... until Glass' eyes flash op

head_text.subj: ON A RATTLESNAKE COILED INCHES FROM HIS FACE

text: Glass stares back in horror... has time to throw up his a in protection as the snake STRIKES... SINKS ITS FANGS INT HIS FOREARM. 41. He shakes it free, but can't escape the snake's next strike... locking its jaws onto Glass' burned throat. Gla opens his mouth to scream.
And Glass' eyes flying open in the glaring sun, as he awa from his nightmare... looks to his arm... no snake. His h instinctively jumps to his melted throat. No bites.
But that's when he hears it... we all do... that same RATTLING FROM HIS DREAM. Glass slowly turns his head towa the sound...
...and there's a RATTLESNAKE COILED just a few feet away. Only it isn't poised to attack Glass. It's facing the oth way, its target a FIELD MOUSE, trapped against a rock.
The snake attacks, sinking its fangs into the mouse. The field mouse tumbles over... quivers as the poison runs through its body, then dies.
As Glass watches the snake begin to make a meal of the mo his hand grips a rock. He drags himself toward the occupi snake... raises the rock high, then SMASHES IT DOWN ON TH SNAKE'S HEAD.

Glass immediately pulls the razor from his bag, and slice off the rattlesnake's head, the field mouse still lodged halfway inside. Glass then drags the razor down the lengt of the snake... digs his fingers under the fresh seam, th peels the outer layer down off the rattler.
With the skin still hanging off the round tube of flesh, Glass BITES INTO THE SNAKE, tearing off a chunk of meat. gobbles it down, slowing only to painfully swallow the fo past his injured throat.
...the head, skin, and not much else.

GLASS - at the water's edge, drinking... touching his charred, melted throat... no leaks. He opens his Possible bag... pulls out the GRIZZLY CLAW NECKLACE... stares at i beat, then slips it over his head. 42.
He drags out the map... spreads it on the ground, then th a glance around him... fingers the point on the blue line a rough guess of his location.
...Fort Union at the top... hundreds of miles north. Fort Brazeau south... but not nearly as far away.

Glass gazes north up the Grand, as if he can see Fitzgera and Bridger just ahead of him. Then he looks back down to his reflection in the water... battered and scarred. He looks to his leg... all but worthless for now... his one arm. It's clear he's not ready to take revenge on anyone.

So Glass shoves the map back into the bag... ties it arou his arm with the powderhorn and blanket, then grabs a THI FALLEN LOG, and rolls it into the river. Glass crawls in behind it... deeper, until the current grows strong enoug carry the weight of his mangled body downstream.
Glass drapes his healthy arm over the log, and starts floating... letting the river do the work. He watches the land move past him faster than it has in days... and with all the agony of every move.
Winding through the open prairie. Glass hangs onto the log... floats with the gentle current.
The sinking sun casts an orange glow over the water. Glas floats downstream... past a HERD OF ELK grazing along the riverbank. The animals don't even notice him.

Dark... the moon hidden behind clouds. A heavy mist hangs over the river. Glass is draped across the log, eyes closed... letting the slow current carry him south. But t his eyes open... because he hears something... a LOW RUMB

Glass looks to the river banks... too foggy to see anythi clearly. The RUMBLE GROWS LOUDER. He peers ahead... too dark to see much... just ANOTHER SPLINTERED LOG floating front of him, its one jagged branch rising up in the air. 43.
But then THE LOG VANISHES. Glass squints through the fog, scanning the surface. But it's gone... the water's empty. that LOW RUMBLE GROWS EVEN LOUDER.

Glass looks to the water beside him... a BRANCH GLIDES PA AT A HIGHER SPEED. And now Glass knows what's coming, but it's too late... because the world suddenly turns upside down, as Glass tumbles over the edge of a TWENTY FOOT WATERFALL.
He spirals downward... crashes into the rushing current. He's washed forward with the suddenly violent rapids. The pull him under the surface, then toss him GASPING back ou

The river carries him blindly through the mist... tossing turning... SLAMMING HIM INTO A HUGE BOULDER... CRACK... h spins off, swept away headfirst... the foaming water suck him down the rocky gauntlet.
He tumbles over more boulders... his Possibles bag snaps loose... Glass makes a grab for it, but is suddenly flipp down another set of falls.
The Possibles Bag is lost in the raging river.
Glass sinks beneath the surface, then floats back up, as rapids calm... spit Glass to the gentle shallows. His bod drifts face-down toward shore.
And just when we're sure Glass has to finally be dead, hi arm reaches up from the water... he digs his fingers into muddy bank, and drags himself out of the river.
Glass collapses unconscious to the ground, his body shrou in that mist.
TIGHT ON THE LEFT SIDE OF GLASS' FACE... the right still pressed into the muddy bank. The sun beats down... then SHADOWS APPEAR... BOUNCE ACROSS HIM... something is stand over Glass.
And then a VULTURE'S HEAD DROPS INTO FRAME...
...latches its beak onto Glass' cheek... tugs at it... stretches it. Glass' eyes pop open... we PULL BACK to see THREE VULTURES surrounding Glass' body, pecking and clawi at his battered wounds. 44.
Glass swings his good arm, knocking one of the vultures a He tries to cry out, but only that PRIMITIVE HISS ERUPTS his throat.
The vultures dance away from his flailing... aren't willi to give up their meal so easily... dart in for quick atta on his flesh.
Glass grasps a branch... swings at the birds, beating the back. The vultures give up the battle... fly away.
Glass crumbles back to the ground... squints up into the sun... the SILHOUETTES OF THE VULTURES CIRCLING ABOVE HIM waiting for him to die.
Glass looks down to his wounds, again oozing blood. He glances around... sees a ridge just a few hundred yards a

At the base of the ridge, a GIANT BOULDER has broken free creating a partial cave. Glass starts crawling toward it. And if it's possible, he looks even closer to death now t when he started this journey.
No more than ten feet deep, but enough to hide from predators. Glass drags himself as far back in the recess he can... collapses against the rock wall.
Glass gathers loose sticks and grass into a small pile... begins sparking rocks together to build a fire.
The fire burns beside Glass, as he TEARS A SINGLE THREAD cloth from the tattered blanket, then feeds it through a hole in a JAGGED, NEEDLE-SIZED SLIVER OF SHARPENED ROCK.. man-made needle and thread.

Glass goes to work on the open wounds of his chest... piercing his skin with the rock... wincing with pain as h tugs the thread through the fresh hole in his skin... pie the other side of the wound, then pulls the flesh tightly together... before repeating the excruciating process all over again... pierce... pull... pierce... tighten. 45.
The moon's glow reflects off the water.
...holding a small sharp stone, and SCRATCHING LETTERS IN THE CAVE'S ROCK WALL.

WE PAN DOWN TO THE GROUND... still listening to the SCRATCHING OF THE ROCK as we glide across the dirt... rea the fire... its flame warm and strong. We TIGHTEN ON THE FIRE, until WE'RE INSIDE IT... and then WE PULL BACK...

...and we see the fire has long died away... just black a The O.S. SCRATCHING has silenced. We glide back across th cave floor... to Glass unconscious on the ground. And abo him on the wall, we see what he had been scratching...
"Robbed and left to die by Fitzgerald and Bridger. If fin eether kill for Hugh Glass"
We hold on those words a beat, then...
DROPS OF RAIN dot the surface. THUNDER RUMBLES... the rai grows heavier.
Rain pouring... gullies of water run down the ridge, spew over the mouth of the cave. But inside, Glass doesn't stir... lying there just as we last saw him.
Rain coming down in buckets. The river's raging.
Clouds drift across the moon... the storm has ended. 46.
Sunny and clear. A rabbit hops along... stops for a momen outside the cave. Beyond it, Glass is still sprawled on t cave floor... he must be dead. The rabbit continues on pa
TIGHT ON GLASS' FACE... as his eyes flutter open. He star straight ahead, unmoving.
Glass crawls out of the crevice... shields his eyes from sun, as he takes in the scene.
The river has sunk back to normal, leaving the banks batt and muddy. The water is thick and brown with all the floo earth it pulled up.

Glass uses all his strength to rise up to his knees, then higher... onto his healthy leg. He braces himself against tree. He's still crooked and hunched over, but for the fi time since the Grizzly attack, he looks more like a man t an animal. He bends down... picks up a BROKEN TREE BRANCH

Glass limps along the bank... beside the brown water stir up from the flood. He moves along the washed-out area, searching for food... grabs some plants... tears them fro the ground to chew on the roots.

He continues on... spots a DEAD SNAPPING TURTLE drowned i the flood, frozen on its back. Glass kneels down to pick the turtle... sniffs it. As he does, he spots something across the river... a DEER, staring back at him.
Glass slowly raises his IMAGINARY RIFLE... takes careful at the deer... pulls the trigger. If only he had his Anst
But then the deer's head snaps... to something beyond Gla Glass follows the animal's eyes... turns to the ridge... the FIVE ARIKARA WARRIORS STANDING AT GLASS' CAVE.
Glass drops flat to the ground behind a tree uprooted in flood. He looks back across the river... THE DEER IS LONG GONE. 47.
Glass inches his head up over the tree... to the warriors crouched outside the cave... studying the tracks.

Glass' eyes jump to the soft dirt along the river... HIS FOOTPRINTS CLEAR... an obvious trail leading right to him He throws a glance around... nowhere to run even if he co So he starts backing into the river on his stomach... fee first... dragging a small branch over the tracks around h wiping them away as he moves. And his eyes are locked on Arikara... watching to see if they spot him.

But they haven't yet, and Glass keeps sliding backward... five feet off shore... only three feet deep in the murky water and sludge. But if he goes any further, the current will catch him... pull him into the next set of violent rapids... and make him a clear target.
The Arikara follow the tracks down from the cave.
Glass sinks neck-deep into the water... the Arikara keep coming... near the river. So Glass drops beneath the surf
And Glass' eyes spread wide... searching the muddy water. grabs a LARGE ROCK... rolls onto his back, and places the rock on his stomach, its weight holding him firmly to the river bottom.
ANGLE ON THE ARIKARA WARRIORS... following Glass' tracks the edge of the river... looking out over the brown river
Glass pressing his head back against the bottom... starin through the cloudy water... to the FIVE SHADOWS STANDING A FEW FEET AWAY.
The Arikara... unknowingly standing just above Glass... looking back to the tracks... scanning the water. But the surface is empty, and the river's too thick with mud to s anything below. 48.

But they keep looking... and we're waiting for Glass to explode from the river, gasping for air. But he doesn't.. and they keep scanning for what seems an eternity, until finally, the warriors turn... start walking back up the p
Behind them, Glass' face inches to the surface... pulls i some oxygen... watches as they fade into the trees.
Then Glass rolls the rock away... starts moving deeper in the river... fighting the current to grab rocks and boulders... pulling himself to the other side.
Glass limps through the trees, still dripping with the mu water of the Grand.
Glass is on his knees, desperately grabbing for a TINY FI MOUSE. The rodent escapes into a hole. Glass claws at the ground after it. He's starving to death.

The rain beating down through the trees. Glass huddles in cluster of bushes, trying to stay dry... shivering in the cold. He reaches out from the cover, grabbing his moccasi boot standing in the rain. He pulls it in... slurps back rainfall that it's caught.
Glass limps slowly across the rolling prairie. He's weak. starving... isn't going to make it much further. He drops his hands and knees.

And then he feels something... the ground almost tremblin under his hands. He watches his hands quiver with vibrati A RUMBLE BUILDS. Glass strains to hear... looks to the cr of a hill... labors up the gentle slope toward the sound.
Glass reaches the crest... looks over the other side to a HERD OF BUFFALO THUNDERING ACROSS THE PRAIRIE. 49.
An incredible site... hundreds of massive creatures... th hooves tearing up the earth, leaving a cloud of dust behi them.
Behind the herd, a PACK OF WOLVES FIGHT OVER A FALLEN BUFFALO.
Glass lies in the high grass, watching the wolves SNARL A SNAP over the remains. And he eyes that buffalo... the closest he's been to food in days.
The five wolves rest around the downed buffalo, their sno bloody from the meal. Suddenly, one of the wolves' heads snaps up... bares its teeth... SNARLS.
And then we see what the wolf is growling at... Glass... limping out of the shadows toward the animals, holding a BURNING SAGE BUSH IN EACH HAND... like giant FLAMING HAND clawing in the night.

The wolves jump to their feet, unsure of what's approachi They growl at Glass. But Glass keeps coming... doing his best to YELL... more like GROWL back at the wolves. He swings the flaming brush, tossing glowing sparks through air.
The wolves spread out, instinctively surrounding Glass. B Glass singles out each one... charges, waving the flames. driving each wolf back.
Four of the wolves back away, but the leader holds its ground... even moves toward Glass... only a few feet away SNARLING... bloody jaws ready to attack, but still not su what its up against.
Glass shakes the flames at the wolf... it SNAPS AT GLASS' ARM. Glass swings the other... slams the fiery plant acro the wolf's head.

The wolf YELPS... leaps back... starts to run away, but t back... makes another charge at Glass. But Glass is ready throws the flaming ball of sage at the wolf, then clubs i with the other. The animal's fur begins to burn.
The frightened wolf has had enough... rolls on the ground then spins to join the rest of its pack. They run a safe distance, then stop... keeping a watch on Glass. 50.
Glass drags the burning sage bushes along the ground, igniting the grass and brush... creating a foot-high flam wall between him and the wolves.
He stretches the flame into a circle, a fiery ring surrou the fallen buffalo.
The wolves have seen enough... turn... race away from the flames.

As the grass around him burns, Glass drops the sage plant attacks the buffalo remains, tearing away bloody chunks o flesh from the carcass, and shoving them into his mouth.. starving animal that's finally found food.
From high above the prairie... Glass and the buffalo at t center of that glowing ring of fire.

The wind's gusting... bending the high golden grass over its side. Glass moves slowly across, pulling his collar u to shield his face from the cold winds. He spots somethin in the distant sky ahead... a THIN LINE OF BLACK SMOKE. Glass picks up his pace... hope spurring him on.
The charred, skeletal remains of a tribe's village... jus black posts where tee-pees once stood... a half-burned lo lodge still smokes, sending that black line into the sky.
Glass limps through the graveyard of structures... all si of life in this village long gone. He searches a basket.. pulls out a BLANKET... wraps it around his shoulders.

Glass steps into the smoky warmth of the lodge... black a empty. He slides down to the floor... unwraps strips of roasted buffalo from what's left of his blanket. He start take a bite, when SOMETHING DARTS PAST THE DOORWAY TO THE BACK ROOM. The O.S. SHUFFLING OF FEET.
Glass freezes... he isn't alone. He rises... grabs a splintered post like a spear... eases toward the doorway. raises the post to swing... 51.
...and sees the SMALL PUPPY standing in the back room. Th dog takes off around a crumbled wall. Glass follows it.

Glass limps across the room... turns the corner of the crumbled wall... and sees the dog slide to a stop beside ANCIENT ARIKARA SQUAW, huddled in the corner, her bony ar outstretched in front of her in weak defense. And her eye are SOLID WHITE... the old woman is blind. She CRIES OUT CHANT over and over... her death chant, as she waits for stranger to kill her.

Glass stands frozen... confused. He tries to speak, but h throat still won't let him. He crouches down in front of old woman... reaches for her hand, but she flails him awa He grabs her again... gently... just holds it until she calms... studying the woman... her hollow face all skin a bones... she's obviously dying.
He pulls the strip of buffalo meat from his pocket... pus it into the squaw's hand. She immediately jerks it to her mouth... and that's when Glass sees the WOMAN HAS NO TEET she can't eat.
Glass turns to an old pot tipped over on the floor.
Glass carries the pot toward a nearby stream. The dog scurries out behind him... follows Glass to the water.

The pot boils over burning logs. Glass dips a cup in, pulling out a warm broth. He carries it to the squaw, sti sitting in the corner... takes her hand, placing the cup it for her. She gulps the liquid back.

Glass goes back to refill the cup. The old woman MUMBLES SOMETHING we can't understand... over and over, as Glass brings the cup back to her. He tries to ease it into her hand, but the woman pushes it away... slides her hand up Glass' arm to his face... patting it... MUMBLING THOSE SA WORDS... thanking Glass. 52.
Glass carries several blankets toward the lodge. The pupp trails behind him, biting at one of the corners... hangin as Glass pulls him across the dirt.
Glass enters the back room with the blankets... stops whe sees the old woman slumped over to the floor, her white e frozen open in a lifeless stare.

Glass has stacked several burned posts into a crude pyre the edge of the village. The squaw lies atop the pyre, covered in the blankets he gathered for her. Glass stands beside the pyre, a FLAMING TORCH in his hand. The puppy rests at his feet.
THREE INDIANS sit on horseback, watching Glass light the pyre... the flames rise into the night.
Glass crouches... pets the dog, as he watches the flames spread... engulf the woman.
...floating into the night. Beyond the sparks, we see something else... THOSE THREE INDIANS GALLOPING TOWARD TH VILLAGE... FAST.
And now Glass sees them too... knows it's too late to run he just stands there. But the dog's seen enough... darts away.
Glass watches the Indians ride into the village... their braided hair and dress is different than the Arikara we'v seen earlier, because these are SIOUX WARRIORS, and Glass knows it.
The Sioux surround Glass on horseback... stare down at Gl The lead warrior (SPOTTED HORSE), (30's), poised and stro points to the flaming pyre... says something to Glass. 53.
Glass tries to answer... can't... touches his scarred thr Spotted Horse slides gracefully off his horse. The other warriors, (THREE FEATHERS and RUNNING FOX) do the same... close in on Glass.

Glass stands firm. Spotted Horse says something else to h Again, Glass touches his throat... holds his jacket out f his sides... no weapons. Spotted Horse studies Glass hard reaches out, wiping his finger down Glass' cheek, almost testing to see if the color comes off.
One of the other warriors pats Glass' hair... smiles... s something to the others. Spotted Horse and the other warr join him, each touching Glass' hair.
Then Spotted Horse spots Glass' necklace... the grizzly c hanging from it. He examines the enormous claw, then nods Glass' stitching and scars.
Griz-lee.
Glass hears the familiar word... nods. Three Feathers pul a WHITE SPECK from the back of Glass' neck... holds it up Spotted Horse.

Spotted Horse jerks out his knife. Glass is confused... holds up his hand, as he takes a step back. But Three Feathers and Running Fox grab Glass... secure him... pull jacket down off his shoulders, exposing his shirt, as Spo Horse walks around behind Glass... raises the knife... Gl GROWLS A PLEA... but Spotted Horse slices the knife down Glass' back... just cutting open his shirt... and reveali

head_text.subj: MASS OF WHITE WORMS... MAGGOTS... COVERING THE DEEP GASHE

text: The three warriors exchange glances... they've obviously never seen anything like this. Glass sees their reaction. throws a nervous glance... what?
Three Feathers runs his hand across Glass' back, dragging HANDFUL OF WORMS for Glass to see. As Glass' eyes widen i panic, Spotted Horse SLAMS THE BUTT OF HIS KNIFE against Glass' head.
Glass drops to his knees... makes a dazed grab for Spotte Horse... misses... and Spotted Horse HITS GLASS AGAIN. Gl tumbles unconscious to the dirt.
Spotted Horse says something to the others... they grab Glass' limp arms... drag him toward the horses. 54.

Dozens of glowing campfires dot the prairie, along with a of tee-pees, their willow poles fanning against the night sky. Animal hides and painted designs decorate the variou tee-pees and lodges. SIOUX CHILDREN laugh and play about village... freeze when they hear Spotted Horse and the ot riders splash across the stream.
The warriors ride into the village, Glass' body tossed ov the back of Three Feather's horse. The children race to t
ANGLE ON GLASS... regaining consciousness... eyes blinkin trying to focus.

head_text.subj: FROM THE BACK OF THE HORSE...

text: ...to the children's eager faces swarming around him... studying this strange face.
Spotted Horse - YELLING SOMETHING at the children... they back away from Glass... fall into line behind the riders.
Sioux MEN and WOMEN watch as the procession moves past... a tee-pee set away from the rest... its hide walls decora with wild lightning bolts and buffalo and vaguely human figures circling the sun.

An OLD MEDICINE MAN, gnarled and leathery, a DEAD RAVEN t in his long hair, his naked chest painted with red and bl stripes, steps out of the tee-pee. He eyes Glass, as Thre Feathers and Running Fox carry him inside.
Suddenly, the Medicine Man begins CHANTING.

head_text.subj: A FLURRY OF IMAGES ACCOMPANIED BY THE MEDICINE MAN'S V.O.
LEATHER STRAPS SNAPPING AROUND GLASS' WRISTS AND ANKLES..

text: stretched tight.
Glass, naked, on his stomach at the center of the tee-pee his arms and legs outstretched, secured to wooden stakes the ground. The white worms cover his back. 55.
The Medicine Man... CHANTING... waving burning sticks in air.
A THICK LIQUID BOILING IN A POT... the Medicine Man's twi hand reaching a gourd container in... filling it with the steaming mixture.
The liquid POURING OVER GLASS' BACK.
GLASS' FACE... arched to the sky... twisted in horrible p He SCREAMS THAT HORRIBLE GROWLING CRY.
MORE IMAGES... even faster... the CHANTING more frantic..
A SIOUX WOMAN,(WAKI), staring down.
HANDS wiping a GREEN SLUDGE over Glass' neck... chest.
The Medicine Man dancing... chanting... shaking sticks li with RATTLESNAKE TAILS.
The moonlight shining through the tee-pee, illuminating t images of the buffalo and dancing shapes.
Waki gently pouring fluid into Glass' mouth.
The Medicine Man holding the SEVERED HEAD OF A SNAKE... lightly sinking the fangs around the wounds on Glass' thr
GLASS' EYES... wide open... rolling up white into his hea
AND THE CHANTING STOPS... the world goes dark.
Cutting through the open prairie. Snow-covered peaks touc the sky in the distance.

Fitzgerald and Bridger trudge their way across the prairi dressed in furs. They rise up a steep slope... reach the top, and spot the cluster of log buildings inside a massi thirty-foot tall wooden fence. Fort Union.
Bridger smiles... relieved.
`Bout goddamn time.
They start down the slope. Fitzgerald grabs Bridger's arm firmly. 56.
And we're understood on everything... Glass' dyin' in his sleep... us buryin' him like was agreed.
Bridger doesn't respond. Fitzgerald doesn't like that.
You're as guilty as me in leavin' him. Don't you forget that. You got a future up here. No sense tossin' it away when he was as good as dead already. Shit, all we did was skip the funeral.
Bridger pulls his arm free... continues on.
I won't take to givin' up that two- hundred on accounta you gettin' weak-kneed.
Bridger keeps walking. Fitzgerald follows behind.

Like a small town surrounded by a log wall. The main TRAD POST BUILDING is busy... TRAPPERS, SIOUX, all with things trade. But most of the life is in the FORT UNION SALOON n door... crowded with customers downstairs, and just as bu in the whores' rooms upstairs.
A small village of tents rests off to the side of the buildings, holding the overflow of traffic.
Fitzgerald and Bridger enter the crowded room... squeeze their way to the bar.
Twice the folks here than when we left.
We should go see Captain Henry.
Far as we hiked... we got time for a drink on the company's tab. 57.
Jim!
They spin... see Pig, Murphy and Stubby Bill sitting at a table. Pig scrambles up... rushes to Bridger, locking him a big bear hug.
You made it! I was scared the `Ree mighta caught up to ya.
If your fat ass could get through, we didn't have no worries.
Pig glares at Fitzgerald... watches him walk to the table joining the others.
(off Fitzgerald, to
Had to be a helluva long walk for you.
Bridger nods... Pig has no idea.
Hugh?
Bridger hesitates a beat, then just shakes his head.
Guess we all knowed how it would turn out. Did he suffer much more?
Another long beat, then...
I hope not.
A PROSTITUTE walks down the stairs... stops on the landin waiting for her next customer. Fitzgerald spots her... grins.
Maybe we best go see Henry, kid. I just got a itch to spend the first of my two-hundred.
The other men laugh. Not Bridger. 58.
Henry sits at his desk. Fitzgerald and Bridger stand acro from him. The others... Pig, Anderson, Murphy, and Stubby Bill crowd the room behind them.
I won't pretend to been his friend, but I respect any man that fights the way he done.
And the grave?
We had those extra days so we went deeper... covered it in rocks. To keep the scavengers off him.
Any sign of hostiles?
Not a one.
The words are like a punch in the gut to Bridger. He can' take the pain... opens his mouth to speak, but Fitzgerald beats him to it.
Truth is, I was worried `bout `Ree, and ready to get movin', but Bridger here argued to stay and make a cross for the grave.
Bridger's head snaps to Fitzgerald... don't make this wor
So that's what we did.
Pig reaches up... gives Bridger a pat on the back. But to Bridger, it feels like a red-hot blade.
Glad to hear you pulled your weight, Mr. Bridger. I knew you would.
More than his share, Captain. 59.
And now Fitzgerald has snared Bridger into his lie. Bridg drops his eyes to his feet.
Speaking of shares.
Henry turns to a SAFE resting against the wall. Fitzgeral watches as Henry spins the dial... locks in the combinati then pulls the latch. The safe door swings open...
...revealing STACKS OF CASH.
Fitzgerald's eyes lock on all that money. Henry pulls out handful... starts counting them out onto the desk.
Am I to assume the agreed arrangement didn't change?
Fortunate for me, it did not.
Well thank you both for your courage and honor. You have done yourselves proud.
Fitzgerald swipes up his pile of bills. Henry drops a cou bills in front of Bridger.
You're owed something for what you did.
Bridger stares down at the bills a beat, then snatches them... pushes his way out of the office before he might to look someone in the eye.
He's beat hisself up most of the trip... wishin' he'da done more.
We all saw the shape Glass was in. There was no more to be done.
That's what I been tellin' him. 60.
Empty, except for Bridger curled up on his cot, squeezing those crumpled bills in his hand, crying.
Glass sleeps under a buffalo robe. His eyes flicker open.

head_text.subj: ON THE BUFFALO AND DANCING FIGURE DESIGNS

text: GLASS - His hand reaching up to his throat. It looks much better than we last saw. And the stitches are gone from h face, now just long, pink scars. He stiffly raises himsel up... remembers his back... struggles to reach behind him scarred but clean... no maggots.
He looks beside him... sees BUCKSKIN PANTS AND SHIRT rest on the ground... waiting for him.
ANGLE ON GLASS... dressed... pushing his way out through flap of the tee-pee... limping out into the midday sun, a shielding his eyes. He looks like a man that hasn't seen light of day for weeks.
Glass adjusts to the brightness... stares in wonder at th scene.
And then we see what Glass is looking at, and understand reaction... the entire village is blanketed in snow. The Sioux VILLAGERS move about, wearing heavy skins and furs.
A WOMEN'S O.S. VOICE turns Glass...

...to WAKI, the woman from the images, walking toward him bundled in fur. She says something else we can't understand... points to Glass' feet. Glass looks down... his BARE FEET BURIED DEEP IN THE SNOW. He hadn't noticed.
And then Waki smiles... a sweet, pretty smile. She takes hand... leads him back into the tee-pee. 61.
Glass and Waki enter. She pulls a pair of moccasins from basket... hands them to Glass.
He slips them on, then presses his fingers against his throat... almost trying to hold it all inside to make it work, then...
(scratching and rough) Thank you.

Waki doesn't understand... just raises a cup of liquid... says something, then touches his throat... motions for hi drink. Glass sips the drink... grimaces... shakes his hea trying to give the cup back, but Waki refuses... points a his throat, and motions for him to drink. Glass stares in the cup a beat, then gulps it back... shakes his head.
Bad medicine.
Waki smiles... hands him his BEAR CLAW NECKLACE. Glass no in thanks, then achingly lifts his arms up to slip it ove his head.
How long have I been here?
Waki just stares back... no idea what Glass said.
You're Sioux. I only know a bit a Pawnee.
Glass stumbles through a sentence of Pawnee. Waki shakes head... throws a jumble of Sioux back at him.
The snow... my healin'. (points to himself) Me. (points to the ground) Here. How long?
Waki shakes her head again. Glass leads her outside. 62.
Glass points to the sun overhead, then raises both hands, fingers outstretched.
How many suns? Ten?
Waki studies Glass... the sun... begins to understand. Sh nods... SAYS A WORD... holds up all ten of her fingers.
Ten suns?
Then Waki closes her hands into fists... opens them again closes them again... SAYS A DIFFERENT WORD.
Christ.

Glass glances around... for the first time, notices Sioux and WOMEN staring at him. Children freeze in the middle o their play... all eyes locked on Glass. TWO SMALL BOYS, ( MOON and LITTLE ONE), repeat the same TWO WORDS to each other...
Tatanka Wicasa.
...over and over.
Glass stares back, unsure. Then...
Buff-A-lo Man.
Glass turns... sees Yellow Horse stepping out of a tee-pe
Spotted Horse (cont'd) (very broken english) What they call you. (points to Glass' hair) Fur of Buff-A-lo.
Glass touches his hair... nods... smiles. The children sm and laugh now too... repeat the words LOUDER.
You speak English.
Need words when trade with whites. 63.
Well I'm grateful for you bringing me here... havin' them care for me. (off Spotted Horse's nod) Now if you could point me which way it is you do your tradin'... with the whites.
Whites. Bra-zo.
Fort Brazeau? That's where I'm tryin' to get. Is it far from here?
Spotted Horse doesn't understand. Glass motions into the distance.
Far? Long way?
Spotted Horse points to a horse, then holds up three fing
Three days on horse?
Spotted Horse nods... looks Glass over, and shakes his he
Not walk. Hides soon.
